Especial attention is given to reduce the Co-60 isotope production. Cobalt-60 is a result of a 59Co nucleus undergoing neutron capture. 60Co decays into 60Ni with a beta decay followed by two high-energy gamma emissions. The quantities of cobalt entering the primary coolant are relatively low compared to the amount of nickel species entering the core, but the probability of activation by neutrons is 170 times that of activating 58Ni. The relatively long half-life and high dose rates mean that 60Co is considered the most hazardous of the activated corrosion products.
